article:
Mary Elizabeth Truss, commonly known as Liz Truss, is a British politician who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from September 2022 to October 2022. She is a member of the Conservative Party and has been the Member of Parliament (MP) for South West Norfolk since 2010.

# Early life and education (1975–1996)

Liz Truss was born on July 26, 1975, in Oxford, England, to John Kenneth Truss and Priscilla Mary Grasby. Her father was a professor of mathematics, and her mother was a nurse and a teacher. Truss grew up in a left-wing household and was educated at a comprehensive school in Leeds. She later attended Merton College, Oxford, where she studied philosophy, politics, and economics (PPE). During her time at Oxford, Truss was an active member of the Liberal Democrats and served as the president of the Oxford University Liberal Democrats.

# Career

## Employment and candidatures (1996–2010)

After graduating from Oxford, Truss worked as an accountant for Shell and later as the deputy director of the think tank Reform. She was also a councillor for the London Borough of Greenwich from 2006 to 2010. Truss stood as a candidate for the Conservative Party in the 2001 general election in the constituency of Hemsworth, but lost to the Labour Party candidate. She was also shortlisted as a candidate for the constituency of Cheltenham in 2005, but ultimately did not secure the nomination.

## Backbencher (2010–2012)

Truss was elected as the MP for South West Norfolk in the 2010 general election, winning the seat with a majority of over 13,000 votes. As a backbencher, Truss was a member of the Free Enterprise Group, a group of Conservative MPs who advocated for free market policies. She also served as a member of the Justice Select Committee and the Education Select Committee.

## Education under-secretary (2012–2014)

In 2012, Truss was appointed as the Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Education and Childcare. In this role, she was responsible for implementing the government's education policies, including the expansion of free schools and the introduction of the phonics test for primary school pupils.

## Environment secretary (2014–2016)

In 2014, Truss was appointed as the Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra). As Environment Secretary, Truss was responsible for implementing the government's policies on agriculture, conservation, and climate change. She also played a key role in the development of the government's strategy for leaving the European Union.

## Justice secretary and lord chancellor (2016–2017)

In 2016, Truss was appointed as the Secretary of State for Justice and Lord Chancellor, making her the first woman to hold the office. As Justice Secretary, Truss was responsible for implementing the government's policies on justice and the rule of law. She also played a key role in the development of the government's strategy for reforming the prison system.

## Chief secretary to the Treasury (2017–2019)

In 2017, Truss was appointed as the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, making her the second woman to hold the office. As Chief Secretary, Truss was responsible for implementing the government's policies on public spending and taxation. She also played a key role in the development of the government's strategy for Brexit.

## International trade secretary (2019–2021)

In 2019, Truss was appointed as the Secretary of State for International Trade. As International Trade Secretary, Truss was responsible for implementing the government's policies on trade and investment. She also played a key role in the development of the government's strategy for negotiating new trade agreements with countries around the world.

## Foreign secretary (2021–2022)

In 2021, Truss was appointed as the Secretary of State for Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Affairs. As Foreign Secretary, Truss was responsible for implementing the government's policies on foreign affairs and development. She also played a key role in the development of the government's strategy for responding to the COVID-19 pandemic.

### Leadership election (July–September 2022)

In July 2022, Truss announced her candidacy for the leadership of the Conservative Party, following the resignation of Boris Johnson as Prime Minister. Truss won the leadership election in September 2022, defeating Rishi Sunak in the final round of voting.

# Premiership (2022)

## Cabinet and death of Elizabeth II

Truss was appointed as Prime Minister on September 6, 2022, following the resignation of Boris Johnson. She became the third female Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, after Margaret Thatcher and Theresa May. Truss's first act as Prime Minister was to appoint a new cabinet, which included several prominent Conservative MPs. Truss also played a key role in the government's response to the death of Queen Elizabeth II, who passed away on September 8, 2022.

## Domestic policies and mini-budget

Truss's government implemented several domestic policies, including a mini-budget that aimed to stimulate economic growth. The mini-budget included several tax cuts and spending increases, which were designed to boost economic activity. However, the mini-budget was widely criticized by economists and opposition politicians, who argued that it would increase inequality and worsen the government's finances.

## Government crisis and resignation

Truss's government faced a major crisis in October 2022, when several Conservative MPs rebelled against the government's policies. The crisis led to the resignation of several government ministers, including the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kwasi Kwarteng. Truss herself resigned as Prime Minister on October 25, 2022, after just 49 days in office. She was succeeded by Rishi Sunak, who became the new Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

# Post-premiership (2022–present)

Truss has remained a member of the Conservative Party and has continued to serve as the MP for South West Norfolk. She has also remained active in politics, speaking out on several issues and advocating for her policies.

# Political positions

## Domestic issues

Truss has taken several positions on domestic issues, including:

* Economy: Truss has advocated for free market policies and has argued that the government should reduce its spending and taxation.
* Education: Truss has advocated for reforms to the education system, including the expansion of free schools and the introduction of the phonics test.
* Justice: Truss has advocated for reforms to the justice system, including the introduction of tougher sentences for serious crimes.

## Foreign policy

Truss has taken several positions on foreign policy issues, including:

* Brexit: Truss has advocated for a hard Brexit, arguing that the United Kingdom should leave the European Union's single market and customs union.
* Trade: Truss has advocated for the negotiation of new trade agreements with countries around the world, arguing that this will boost economic growth.
* Security: Truss has advocated for increased spending on defense, arguing that this is necessary to protect the United Kingdom's national security.

article:
Forbidden Door (2022)

Forbidden Door was a professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event produced by All Elite Wrestling (AEW) in partnership with New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW). The event took place on June 26, 2022, at the United Center in Chicago, Illinois.

# Production

## Background

Forbidden Door was a historic event, marking the first-ever joint pay-per-view event between AEW and NJPW. The partnership between the two promotions was announced in February 2022, with the event being officially confirmed in April. The event was seen as a major milestone in the professional wrestling industry, bringing together two of the world's top promotions for a unique and exciting event.

## Storylines

The event featured a series of matches that were built up through storylines in the weeks leading up to the event. One of the main storylines centered around the AEW Interim World Championship Eliminator Series, a tournament that would determine the interim champion of the AEW World Championship. The tournament featured eight wrestlers from AEW and NJPW, competing in a single-elimination bracket.

Another major storyline revolved around the AEW All-Atlantic Championship, a new title that was introduced at the event. The inaugural champion would be determined through a tournament featuring wrestlers from AEW, NJPW, and other promotions.

# Event

## The Buy-In

The event kicked off with The Buy-In, a pre-show that featured a series of matches and segments. The Buy-In was streamed live on AEW's YouTube channel and other social media platforms.

## Preliminary matches

The main card of the event featured a series of preliminary matches, including a match between Orange Cassidy and Will Ospreay, and a tag team match between the Young Bucks and El Phantasmo and Ishii.

## Main event

The main event of the evening saw Jon Moxley defeat Hiroshi Tanahashi to become the interim AEW World Champion. The match was a highly anticipated bout, with both men delivering a standout performance.

# Aftermath

The event received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising the unique blend of AEW and NJPW styles. The event was also a commercial success, with the United Center selling out in advance.

The aftermath of the event saw a number of storylines continue to unfold, including the build-up to the AEW All-Atlantic Championship tournament final.

# Results

## AEW Interim World Championship Eliminator Series bracket

* Jon Moxley defeated Hiroshi Tanahashi in the final to become the interim AEW World Champion
* Eliminator Series matches:
	+ Jon Moxley defeated Kyle O'Reilly
	+ Hiroshi Tanahashi defeated Andrade El Idolo
	+ Kyle O'Reilly defeated Rey Fénix
	+ Jon Moxley defeated Satoshi Kojima
	+ Andrade El Idolo defeated Drew Parker
	+ Hiroshi Tanahashi defeated Dante Martin

## AEW All-Atlantic Championship inaugural tournament bracket

* The tournament is ongoing, with the final set to take place at a future date

* AEW All-Atlantic Championship

She wrote about topics such as the rise of Instagram, the impact of social media on relationships, and the growing influence of online influencers.

This article provides an overview of the background, wildfires, domestic impacts, international effects, fatalities, domestic government responses, and other reactions related to the 2023 Canadian wildfires.

# Background

Canada is prone to wildfires due to its vast forests and dry climate, particularly in the western provinces. The country experiences an average of 8,000 wildfires per year, with the majority occurring in the provinces of Alberta, British Columbia, and Saskatchewan. The 2023 Canadian wildfires also had significant political impacts, particularly in the provinces of Alberta and British Columbia, where the fires were most severe.

article:
North Kosovo Crisis (2022–2024)

The North Kosovo crisis was a period of heightened tensions and conflict between Kosovo and Serbia, specifically in the north of Kosovo, which is predominantly inhabited by ethnic Serbs. The crisis began in 2022 and lasted for nearly two years, with multiple incidents and escalations occurring throughout the period.

# Background

Kosovo declared independence from Serbia in 2008, but the status of the region remains disputed. The north of Kosovo, which is home to a majority of the country's ethnic Serb population, has historically been a point of contention between the two countries. Serbia does not recognize Kosovo as a sovereign state and views the north as part of its own territory. Kosovo, on the other hand, claims sovereignty over the entire territory.

In the years leading up to the crisis, tensions between Kosovo and Serbia had been simmering. Efforts to normalize relations between the two countries had stalled, and incidents of violence and intimidation against ethnic Serbs in Kosovo had increased. The situation was further complicated by the presence of parallel institutions in the north, which were established by Serbia and maintained a degree of autonomy from the Kosovo government.

# Timeline

## 2022

### July

The crisis began in July 2022, when Kosovo's government announced plans to introduce a new license plate system, which would replace existing plates issued by Serbia. The move was seen as an attempt to assert Kosovo's authority over the north and was met with resistance from local Serbs. Protests erupted in the town of Mitrovica, with demonstrators blocking roads and clashing with police.

### August

Tensions escalated in August, when Kosovo's police attempted to enforce the new license plate system in the north. Clashes broke out between police and local Serbs, resulting in several injuries and arrests. Serbia's government condemned the actions of Kosovo's police and accused them of attempting to ethnically cleanse the north.

### September

In September, the situation took a turn for the worse, when a group of masked men attacked a police station in the north. The attack was blamed on Kosovo's government, which denied any involvement. Serbia's government responded by deploying troops to the border with Kosovo, citing concerns for the safety of ethnic Serbs.

### October

October saw a significant escalation of the crisis, when Kosovo's government announced plans to hold local elections in the north. The move was seen as an attempt to assert Kosovo's authority over the region and was met with resistance from local Serbs. Protests erupted, and clashes broke out between police and demonstrators.

### November

During the 2022 FIFA World Cup, there were several incidents involving LGBT symbols, particularly the rainbow flag and OneLove armbands.

## Captains' armbands

England, Wales, Belgium, Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands, and Switzerland had planned to wear OneLove armbands, which feature a rainbow flag and the words "OneLove" in a circle. However, on the morning of the first matchday, FIFA announced that players would receive yellow cards if they wore the armbands. In response, the seven teams involved announced that they would not wear the armbands, citing the threat of yellow cards and the potential impact on their players.

For example, the German team covered their mouths during a team photo before their match against Japan, in protest of FIFA's decision. 2022 European Women's Handball Championship

The 2022 European Women's Handball Championship was the 16th edition of the European Women's Handball Championship, a quadrennial handball tournament for women's national teams organized by the European Handball Federation (EHF). The tournament was held in Slovenia, North Macedonia, and Montenegro from November 4 to November 20, 2022.

# Bidding process

The bidding process for the 2022 European Women's Handball Championship began in 2018. The EHF invited member federations to submit bids to host the tournament.

## Bidding timeline

* June 2018: Bidding process opened

* November 2018: Evaluation of bids
* December 2018: Announcement of host countries

## Bids

Two bids were submitted to host the tournament:

* Slovenia, North Macedonia, and Montenegro (joint bid)
* Hungary and Slovakia (joint bid)

The EHF announced on December 20, 2018, that Slovenia, North Macedonia, and Montenegro would host the 2022 European Women's Handball Championship.

# Venues

The tournament was held in six venues across the three host countries:

* Slovenia: Arena Stožice (Ljubljana), Zlatorog Arena (Celje), and Podmežakla Hall (Ljubljana)
* North Macedonia: Boris Trajkovski Sports Center (Skopje) and Jane Sandanski Arena (Skopje)
* Montenegro: Morača Sports Center (Podgorica)

The Amazing Race Australia 6 is the sixth season of the Australian reality television game show The Amazing Race Australia, which premiered on Network 10 on August 30, 2022. The season features 20 teams of two, each with a pre-existing relationship, competing in a race around the world to win a grand prize of A$250,000.

# Production

## Development and filming

The Amazing Race Australia 6 was announced on October 20, 2021, with Network 10 confirming that the show would be returning for a sixth season. Filming took place from February to April 2022, with teams traveling to 12 countries across five continents. The show was hosted by Beau Ryan, who returned for his third season as host.

## Casting

Casting for The Amazing Race Australia 6 began in October 2021, with an open casting call for teams of two. The casting process involved an online application, followed by in-person auditions and interviews. The final 20 teams were selected from thousands of applicants and were announced on July 27, 2022.

## Marketing

Network 10 launched a marketing campaign for The Amazing Race Australia 6 in July 2022, which included promotional trailers, social media advertising, and print media. The show's official website also featured exclusive content, including team profiles and behind-the-scenes footage.

The first leg of The Amazing Race Australia 6 began in Sydney, with teams flying to Casablanca, Morocco. The first challenge was a Detour, where teams had to choose between "Camel Ride" or "Market Mayhem". The first team to arrive at the Pit Stop, located at the Hassan II Mosque, won a A$5,000 cash prize.

## Leg 2 (Australia → Morocco)

The second leg saw teams traveling to Marrakech, Morocco. The Roadblock challenge was "Snake Charmer", where one team member had to navigate a snake-filled maze to retrieve a clue. The first team to arrive at the Pit Stop, located at the Bahia Palace, won a A$5,000 cash prize.

Battle of Bakhmut

The Battle of Bakhmut was a prolonged and intense military engagement between Ukrainian and Russian forces in the city of Bakhmut, Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine. The battle began in August 2022 and lasted for nearly a year, with both sides suffering significant losses. It was one of the bloodiest and most destructive battles of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.

#Background

The city of Bakhmut, with a pre-war population of around 70,000, is a strategically important location in eastern Ukraine. It is situated near the intersection of several major roads and is close to the city of Kramatorsk, a key Ukrainian military hub. Bakhmut is also home to several important industrial facilities, including a salt mine and a winery.

Prior to the Russian invasion, Bakhmut was a relatively quiet city, with a strong sense of community and a growing tourism industry. However, as the conflict escalated in 2022, the city became a key target for Russian forces seeking to capture the Donetsk region.

#Battle

The Battle of Bakhmut was a complex and multifaceted engagement that can be divided into several distinct phases.

##Early shelling and Russian encroachment (August–October 2022)

The battle began in August 2022, as Russian forces started shelling Bakhmut with artillery and rockets. The Ukrainian military responded with counter-battery fire, but the Russian attacks continued to intensify. As the weeks passed, Russian forces began to encroach on the city's outskirts, capturing several key villages and settlements.

##Early winter escalation (November–December 2022)

As winter approached, the battle escalated further. Russian forces launched a series of ground assaults against Ukrainian positions, but were repeatedly repelled. The Ukrainian military, meanwhile, began to dig in, establishing a network of trenches and fortifications around the city.

##Capture of Soledar and partial encirclement (January–April 2023)

In January 2023, Russian forces captured the nearby town of Soledar, which gave them control of the main road into Bakhmut. The Ukrainian military responded by launching a series of counterattacks, but were unable to retake the town. As the weeks passed, Russian forces continued to tighten their grip on Bakhmut, capturing several key villages and settlements to the north and south of the city.

##Ukrainian flanking counterattacks begin (May 2023)

In May 2023, the Ukrainian military launched a series of flanking counterattacks against Russian positions to the north and south of Bakhmut. The attacks were designed to relieve pressure on the city and disrupt Russian supply lines. The counterattacks were initially successful, but were eventually repelled by Russian forces.

##Capture of Bakhmut and Wagner withdrawal (20 May–early June 2023)

On May 20, 2023, Russian forces captured the center of Bakhmut, marking a major turning point in the battle. The Ukrainian military withdrew from the city, and Russian forces began to consolidate their gains. However, in early June 2023, the Wagner Group, a Russian mercenary outfit that had played a key role in the battle, announced that it was withdrawing from Bakhmut due to heavy losses.

#Military strength and tactics

The military strength and tactics employed during the Battle of Bakhmut were complex and multifaceted.

* Russian forces: The Russian military employed a range of tactics during the battle, including artillery bombardments, ground assaults, and drone strikes. * Ukrainian forces: The Ukrainian military, meanwhile, employed a range of tactics, including counter-battery fire, ambushes, and flanking counterattacks. They also made use of drones and artillery to target Russian positions.

#Aftermath

The aftermath of the Battle of Bakhmut was marked by significant destruction and loss of life.

The capture of Bakhmut gave Russian forces control of a key strategic location in eastern Ukraine. However, the city's value was largely symbolic, as it did not provide a significant military advantage.

article:
Angela Lansbury

Dame Angela Lansbury is a renowned British-American actress whose career spans over seven decades. Born on October 16, 1925, in London, England, Lansbury has established herself as one of the most versatile and accomplished actresses of her generation. With a career that encompasses film, television, and theater, Lansbury has captivated audiences with her unique blend of wit, charm, and talent.

#Early life and career beginnings

##Childhood: 1925–1942

Angela Lansbury was born in Regent's Park, London, to Edgar Lansbury, a timber merchant, and Belfast-born Moyna Macgill, a actress. She was the first of four children, including twin brothers Edgar and Bruce, and a sister, Isolde. Lansbury's early life was marked by her mother's career in theater, which exposed her to the performing arts from a young age. The family moved to the United States in 1940, settling in New York City.

##Career breakthrough: 1942–1945

Lansbury's introduction to the film industry came at the age of 16, when she signed a contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) in 1942. Her film debut was in the 1944 film "Gaslight," opposite Ingrid Bergman and Charles Boyer. Lansbury's portrayal of Nancy Oliver, a cockney maid, earned her an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress. This early success marked the beginning of a long and fruitful association with MGM.

##Later MGM films: 1945–1951

Throughout the late 1940s and early 1950s, Lansbury appeared in a string of films for MGM, including "The Picture of Dorian Gray" (1945), "The Harvey Girls" (1946), and "State of the Union" (1948). Her performances showcased her range and versatility, solidifying her position as a rising star in Hollywood.

#Mid career

##The Manchurian Candidate and minor roles: 1952–1965

In the 1950s and 1960s, Lansbury's career experienced a slight downturn, with fewer leading roles and more minor appearances. One notable exception was her portrayal of Eleanor Iselin in the 1962 film "The Manchurian Candidate," opposite Frank Sinatra and Laurence Harvey. Her performance earned her a second Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress.

##Mame and theatrical stardom: 1966–1969

Lansbury's career resurgence began in the late 1960s, when she took on the title role in the Broadway musical "Mame." Her performance as the eccentric and charismatic Mame Dennis earned her widespread critical acclaim and a Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical. This success marked a turning point in Lansbury's career, as she transitioned from film to theater and established herself as a leading lady of the stage.

##Ireland and Gypsy: 1970–1978

In the 1970s, Lansbury continued to work in theater, appearing in productions such as "Gypsy" (1974) and "The King and I" (1977). She also began to explore her Irish heritage, purchasing a home in County Cork and becoming involved in local charitable organizations.

##Sweeney Todd and continued cinematic work: 1979–1984

In 1979, Lansbury starred as Mrs. Lovett in the Broadway musical "Sweeney Todd," opposite Len Cariou. Her performance earned her a second Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical. Throughout the early 1980s, Lansbury continued to appear in films, including "The Mirror Crack'd" (1980) and "The Company of Wolves" (1984).

#Global fame

##Murder, She Wrote: 1984–2003

Lansbury's most iconic role came in 1984, when she began starring as Jessica Fletcher in the CBS television series "Murder, She Wrote." The show, which followed the adventures of a mystery novelist and amateur sleuth, became a global phenomenon, airing for 12 seasons and earning Lansbury numerous awards and nominations, including 12 Emmy nominations for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series.

##Final years: 2003–2022

In the 2000s, Lansbury continued to work in film and television, appearing in productions such as "Nanny McPhee" (2005) and "Little Women" (2017). She also remained active in theater, starring in productions such as "Blithe Spirit" (2009) and "A Little Night Music" (2009).

#Personal life

Lansbury has been married twice, first to actor Richard Cromwell from 1945 until their divorce in 1946, and then to actor Peter Shaw from 1949 until his death in 2003. She has two children, Anthony and Deirdre, and several grandchildren.

#Honours and legacy

Throughout her career, Lansbury has been recognized with numerous awards and honors, including six Tony Awards, three Academy Award nominations, and 12 Emmy nominations. She was appointed a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in 1994 and was elevated to Dame Commander (DBE) in 2014. Lansbury's legacy as a pioneering actress and advocate for the arts continues to inspire new generations of performers and audiences alike.

#Publications

Lansbury has written two autobiographies, "Sheltered Daughters" (1983) and "Balancing Act" (1999), which offer a unique glimpse into her life and career.

* List of Emmy Award winners

#Notes

This article is a comprehensive overview of Angela Lansbury's life and career, drawing on a range of sources and biographical information.

article:
2022 Asian Men's Volleyball Cup

The 2022 Asian Men's Volleyball Cup was the seventh edition of the Asian Men's Volleyball Cup, a biennial international volleyball tournament organized by the Asian Volleyball Confederation (AVC). The tournament was held from August 7 to August 14, 2022, in Pasig, Philippines.

# Host selection

The Philippines was announced as the host country for the 2022 Asian Men's Volleyball Cup in November 2021. This was the first time the country hosted the tournament.

# Qualification

A total of 11 teams qualified for the tournament. The qualification process was based on the teams' performance at the 2021 Asian Men's Volleyball Championship.

## Qualified teams

*  Australia
*  China
*  Chinese Taipei
*  Iran
*  Japan
*  Kazakhstan
*  Qatar
*  Saudi Arabia
*  South Korea
*  Thailand
*  Uzbekistan

# Pools composition

The 11 qualified teams were divided into four pools of three teams each, with the top two teams from each pool advancing to the classification round. The pools were formed based on the teams' performance at the 2021 Asian Men's Volleyball Championship.

# Venues

The tournament was held at the PhilSports Arena in Pasig, Philippines.

# Pool standing procedure

The teams were ranked according to the number of matches won, with the following criteria used to break ties:

* Number of matches won
* Sets quotient (sets won divided by sets lost)
* Points quotient (points scored divided by points conceded)

article:
Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt (Hessian State Museum Darmstadt) is a museum of art, cultural history, and natural history located in Darmstadt, Germany. It is one of the oldest and largest museums in the state of Hesse, with a collection of over 700,000 objects. The museum's diverse collections range from prehistoric artifacts to contemporary art, and its exhibitions and programs aim to engage audiences in the cultural and natural heritage of the region.

#History

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt was founded in 1820 by Grand Duke Louis I of Hesse, who recognized the importance of preserving and showcasing the cultural and natural heritage of the region. Initially, the museum was housed in the grand ducal palace in Darmstadt, but as the collections grew, it became necessary to find a larger and more suitable location. In 1902, the museum moved to its current building, which was designed by the architect Alfred Messel.

Over the years, the museum has undergone several transformations, with new departments and collections being added. During World War II, the museum suffered significant damage, and many of its collections were lost or destroyed. After the war, the museum underwent a major reconstruction effort, and many of its collections were rebuilt through donations and purchases.

#Building

##Location

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt is located in the heart of Darmstadt, on the Friedensplatz. The museum's building is a prominent example of late 19th-century museum architecture, with a mix of Art Nouveau and historicist styles. The building's facade is decorated with sculptures and reliefs, which reflect the museum's diverse collections.

##Renovations and extensions

In recent years, the museum has undergone several renovations and extensions. In 2008, the museum completed a major renovation of its building, which included the restoration of the original facade and the installation of modern climate control and security systems. In 2015, the museum opened a new wing, designed by the architect Volker Staab, which provides additional exhibition space and improved facilities for visitors.

#Collections

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt has a diverse range of collections, which reflect the cultural and natural heritage of the region. The museum's collections include:

* Prehistoric artifacts, including tools, ceramics, and jewelry
* Ancient Greek and Roman art and artifacts
* Medieval and Renaissance art and artifacts, including sculptures, paintings, and textiles
* Baroque and Rococo art and artifacts, including furniture, ceramics, and glass
* 19th- and 20th-century art, including paintings, sculptures, and installations
* Natural history collections, including fossils, minerals, and taxidermied animals
* Ethnographic collections, including artifacts from Africa, Asia, and the Americas

#Gallery

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt has a number of permanent galleries, which showcase the museum's diverse collections. Some of the galleries include:

* The Prehistoric Gallery, which features artifacts from the Paleolithic to the Iron Age
* The Ancient Gallery, which features art and artifacts from ancient Greece and Rome
* The Medieval and Renaissance Gallery, which features art and artifacts from the Middle Ages to the Renaissance
* The Baroque and Rococo Gallery, which features art and artifacts from the 17th and 18th centuries
* The 19th- and 20th-Century Gallery, which features art from the modern period
* The Natural History Gallery, which features fossils, minerals, and taxidermied animals
* The Ethnographic Gallery, which features artifacts from Africa, Asia, and the Americas

#Special exhibitions

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt also hosts a number of special exhibitions throughout the year, which showcase the museum's collections and engage audiences in the cultural and natural heritage of the region. Recent special exhibitions have included:

* "The Art of the Renaissance in Hesse"
* "The Natural History of the Odenwald"
* "The Art of the 20th Century in Hesse"
* "The Cultural Heritage of Africa in Hesse"

#Controversies

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt has been involved in several controversies over the years, including debates over the ownership and repatriation of cultural artifacts. In 2013, the museum returned a number of artifacts to their countries of origin, including a collection of ancient Egyptian artifacts that were looted during the colonial period.

The 2023 World Men's Curling Championship was the 65th edition of the World Men's Curling Championship, which was held from April 1 to 9, 2023, at the Basalda Stadium in Basel, Switzerland.

Summary
--------

The 2023 World Men's Curling Championship was contested by 13 teams from around the world. The teams competed in a round-robin format, with the top six teams advancing to the playoffs. # Alexander Suvorov

Alexander Vasilyevich Suvorov (1730-1800) was a renowned Russian military commander, statesman, and writer, who is widely regarded as one of the greatest military minds in history. He is known for his exceptional leadership, strategic genius, and innovative tactics, which earned him numerous victories and accolades throughout his illustrious career.

# Early Life

## Origins

Alexander Suvorov was born on November 24, 1730, in Moscow, Russia, to a family of minor nobility. His father, Vasily Ivanovich Suvorov, was a military officer who had served in the Russian army during the Great Northern War.

## Childhood

Suvorov's childhood was marked by a strong interest in military affairs, which was encouraged by his father. He was educated at home, where he developed a passion for reading and writing. Suvorov's early life was also influenced by his mother, Avdotya Fedorovna Suvorova, who instilled in him a strong sense of morality and compassion.

# Early Career

## First Military Experience

Suvorov's military career began in 1748, when he enlisted in the Russian army as a private. He quickly rose through the ranks, becoming a lieutenant in 1754. Suvorov's early military experience was marked by service in the Seven Years' War, where he fought against Prussian forces.

## 1761

In 1761, Suvorov was appointed as the commander of the Astrakhan Regiment, which was stationed in the Caucasus region. This marked the beginning of his rise to prominence as a military commander.

## Freemasonry, Berlin

In 1762, Suvorov became a member of the Freemasons, a secret society that emphasized the values of brotherhood, morality, and intellectual pursuits. He also visited Berlin, where he met with prominent intellectuals and military leaders, including Frederick the Great.

# Wars against Poland-Lithuania

## Dissolution of the Bar Confederation (1768-1772)

### Outbreak of War and Setbacks

In 1768, Suvorov was appointed as the commander of Russian forces in Poland, where he was tasked with suppressing the Bar Confederation, a Polish uprising against Russian rule. The war began with a series of setbacks for Russian forces, including the defeat of Suvorov's troops at the Battle of Lancut.

### Retaliatory Strike

However, Suvorov quickly regrouped and launched a retaliatory strike against Polish forces, which resulted in a series of victories for Russian troops. The war ultimately ended with the dissolution of the Bar Confederation and the partitioning of Poland between Russia, Prussia, and Austria.

## Battles against Polish Uprising (1794)

### Turning Victories

In 1794, Suvorov was once again appointed as the commander of Russian forces in Poland, where he was tasked with suppressing a new Polish uprising. The war began with a series of turning victories for Russian forces, including the Battle of Krupczyce and the Battle of Terespol.

### Triumph and Tragedy in Praga

The war culminated in the Battle of Praga, where Russian forces defeated Polish troops and captured the city of Warsaw. However, the victory was marred by tragedy, as Russian troops massacred thousands of Polish civilians in the city.

### Culmination, Impact of Campaign

The war ultimately ended with the defeat of Polish forces and the partitioning of Poland between Russia, Prussia, and Austria. Suvorov's victories in Poland cemented his reputation as a brilliant military commander and earned him widespread acclaim throughout Europe.

# Wars with the Ottoman Empire

## 1st War against the Ottomans

### Developments

In 1768, Suvorov was appointed as the commander of Russian forces in the Caucasus region, where he was tasked with fighting against Ottoman forces. The war began with a series of developments, including the capture of the city of Azov and the defeat of Ottoman forces at the Battle of Kagul.

## 2nd War against the Ottomans

### Beginning

In 1787, Suvorov was once again appointed as the commander of Russian forces in the Caucasus region, where he was tasked with fighting against Ottoman forces. The war began with a series of battles, including the Battle of Focsani and the Battle of Rymnik.

### The Apex of Military Deeds

The war culminated in the Battle of Izmail, where Russian forces defeated Ottoman troops and captured the city of Izmail. This marked the apex of Suvorov's military deeds and cemented his reputation as one of the greatest military commanders in history.

# Cossack Rebellion (1774)

## In the Footsteps of Pugachev

In 1774, Suvorov was appointed as the commander of Russian forces in the Caucasus region, where he was tasked with suppressing a Cossack rebellion led by Emelyan Pugachev. The rebellion was ultimately crushed, and Pugachev was captured and executed.

# Kuban and Crimea

## Kuban

In 1783, Suvorov was appointed as the commander of Russian forces in the Kuban region, where he was tasked with fighting against Ottoman forces. The war began with a series of battles, including the Battle of Anapa and the Battle of Sukhum.

## Crimea (Little Tartary)

### Christian Resettlement

In 1784, Suvorov was appointed as the commander of Russian forces in Crimea, where he was tasked with resettling Christian populations in the region.

### Kherson

In 1785, Suvorov was appointed as the governor of Kherson, a city in southern Ukraine. He played a key role in the development of the city and the surrounding region.

### Tulchin

In 1789, Suvorov was appointed as the commander of Russian forces in Tulchin, a city in southern Ukraine. He played a key role in the development of the city and the surrounding region.

# Finland (1791-1792)

In 1791, Suvorov was appointed as the commander of Russian forces in Finland, where he was tasked with fighting against Swedish forces. The war began with a series of battles, including the Battle of Svensksund and the Battle of Björneborg.

# Relations with Paul

Suvorov had a complex relationship with Paul I, the Emperor of Russia. While Suvorov was a brilliant military commander, Paul was a difficult and demanding ruler. The two men often clashed, and Suvorov was eventually dismissed from his position as commander of Russian forces.

# Italian and Swiss Expedition of 1799

## Italian Campaign

Jane Birkin is a British actress and singer who has been active in the entertainment industry since the 1960s. She is best known for her iconic collaborations with French singer-songwriter Serge Gainsbourg and her distinctive voice, which has been featured in numerous films and recordings.

# Early life

Jane Birkin was born on December 14, 1946, in Marylebone, London, England, to David Birkin, a World War II naval lieutenant commander, and Judy Campbell, an actress. She has a brother, Andrew Birkin, who is also an actor and director. Birkin's early life was marked by her parents' separation and her mother's remarriage to actor Peter Birkin. She was educated at the Arts Educational School in London and later attended the École Jeannine Manuel in Paris.

# Career

## Early acting credits

Birkin began her acting career as a teenager, appearing in small roles on British television and in film. Her early credits include the 1966 film "The Knack... and How to Get It" and the 1967 television series " Armchair Theatre." In the late 1960s, she moved to France and began working in the country's thriving film industry.

## Collaborations with Serge Gainsbourg

Birkin's most notable collaborations are with French singer-songwriter Serge Gainsbourg, whom she met on the set of the 1969 film "Slogan." The two began a romantic relationship and worked together on numerous projects, including the iconic 1969 song "Je T'aime... Moi Non Plus," which was banned in several countries due to its explicit content. The song's success led to a series of albums and singles, including "Di Doo Dah" and "Ex Fan des Sixties."

Birkin's collaborations with Gainsbourg are widely regarded as some of the most influential and innovative works of the 1970s. Their partnership combined Gainsbourg's poetic lyrics and eclectic musical style with Birkin's distinctive voice and androgynous persona.

## Later performances and recordings

In the 1980s and 1990s, Birkin continued to work in film and music, releasing several solo albums and appearing in a range of French and international productions. Her later collaborations include work with French singer-songwriter Étienne Daho and the 1994 album "Versions Jane," which featured reinterpretations of songs by Gainsbourg and other artists.

# Personal life

## Death

Birkin's partner, Serge Gainsbourg, died on March 2, 1991, at the age of 62. The couple had a daughter, Charlotte Gainsbourg, who is also an actress and singer.

## Philanthropy

Birkin is involved with several charitable organizations, including Amnesty International and the French organization, Médecins Sans Frontières (Doctors Without Borders).

## Political views and activism

Birkin has been an outspoken advocate for human rights and social justice. In 2011, she was involved in a high-profile campaign to raise awareness about the plight of refugees in France.

# Awards and honours

Birkin has received numerous awards and honours for her contributions to film and music. In 1992, she was awarded the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres by the French government.

# In popular culture

## Birkin basket

The "Birkin basket" is a style of wicker basket bag that was popularized by Birkin in the 1970s. The bag, which was designed by Hermès, has become a fashion icon and is still widely popular today.

## Birkin bag

The "Birkin bag" is a luxury handbag designed by Hermès and named after Birkin. The bag is widely regarded as one of the most iconic and desirable handbags in the world.

title: Mount_Omurga
article:
# Mount Omurga

Mount Omurga is a mountain peak located in the Tashkent Region of Uzbekistan. With an elevation of 3,934 meters (12,907 feet) above sea level, it is one of the highest peaks in the Tian Shan mountain range. The mountain is known for its unique geological features, diverse flora and fauna, and its cultural significance in the region.

# Geography and Climate

## Location and Topography

Mount Omurga is situated in the Tian Shan mountain range, which stretches across several countries in Central Asia, including Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, and Kazakhstan. The mountain is located in the Pskem River valley, approximately 30 kilometers (19 miles) east of the city of Tashkent. The peak is part of the larger Tian Shan mountain system, which is characterized by rugged terrain, steep slopes, and glaciers.

## Climate

The climate on Mount Omurga is continental, with cold winters and mild summers. The average temperature in January, the coldest month, is around -10°C (14°F), while the average temperature in July, the warmest month, is around 15°C (59°F). The mountain receives significant precipitation, with an average annual rainfall of around 1,000 millimeters (39 inches). The snow season typically lasts from November to April, with the peak receiving heavy snowfall during this period.

# Geology

## Geological History

Mount Omurga is composed of ancient rocks, including granite, gneiss, and schist, which date back to the Paleozoic Era. The mountain is part of the Tian Shan orogenic belt, which was formed as a result of the collision between the Eurasian and Indian tectonic plates. The mountain-building process, which occurred around 250 million years ago, resulted in the formation of the Tian Shan mountain range, including Mount Omurga.

## Mineral Resources

The mountain is rich in mineral resources, including copper, lead, and zinc. The surrounding valleys and slopes of the mountain are home to several mines, which extract these minerals. The mineral deposits are believed to have formed as a result of hydrothermal activity, which occurred during the mountain-building process.

# Flora and Fauna

## Vegetation

The mountain is home to a diverse range of flora, including alpine meadows, forests, and scrublands. The lower slopes of the mountain are covered with deciduous forests, including species such as birch, beech, and walnut. The higher slopes are home to coniferous forests, including species such as spruce, fir, and cedar. The alpine meadows, which are found above the tree line, are characterized by a variety of wildflowers, including edelweiss, gentian, and primrose.

## Wildlife

The mountain is home to a variety of wildlife, including several endangered species. The mountain is a habitat for the snow leopard, which is found in the higher reaches of the mountain. Other species found on the mountain include the Tien Shan bear, the golden eagle, and the ibex. The mountain is also home to several species of birds, including the saker falcon, the peregrine falcon, and the bearded vulture.

# Cultural Significance

## History

Mount Omurga has significant cultural and historical importance in the region. The mountain has been considered sacred by the local population for centuries, and is believed to have healing properties. The mountain was also an important center of trade and commerce, with several ancient trade routes passing through the surrounding valleys.

## Tourism

The mountain is a popular destination for tourists, who come to the region to experience the natural beauty and cultural heritage of the area. The mountain offers several trekking and hiking routes, including the popular Omurga Trek, which takes tourists to the summit of the mountain. The surrounding valleys and villages offer a range of accommodation options, including guesthouses, homestays, and camping sites.

# Conservation Efforts

## Protected Areas

The mountain is part of the Tian Shan Biosphere Reserve, which was established in 2006 to protect the natural and cultural heritage of the region. The reserve covers an area of over 1,000 square kilometers (386 square miles) and is home to several endangered species, including the snow leopard and the Tien Shan bear.

## Sustainable Tourism

The local authorities have implemented several initiatives to promote sustainable tourism in the region. These include the development of eco-tourism infrastructure, such as environmentally-friendly accommodation options and waste management systems. The authorities have also implemented measures to protect the natural environment, including the establishment of protected areas and the regulation of human activity in sensitive ecosystems.

# Conclusion

Mount Omurga is a unique and fascinating destination that offers a range of opportunities for outdoor enthusiasts, nature lovers, and cultural tourists. The mountain's diverse flora and fauna, its rich cultural heritage, and its stunning natural beauty make it a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring the natural and cultural wonders of Central Asia.

article:
Armorial of Albania
=====================

The Armorial of Albania is a collection of coats of arms used by Albanian noble families, feudal lords, and various states and territories throughout history. The use of coats of arms in Albania dates back to the Middle Ages, and over time, various styles and traditions have emerged, reflecting the country's complex history and cultural influences.

Medieval Period
---------------

During the Middle Ages, Albania was a battleground for various empires and states, including the Byzantine Empire, the Kingdom of Serbia, and the Venetian Republic. As a result, the use of coats of arms in Albania was heavily influenced by these external powers.

### Ambiguitatem

The earliest known use of coats of arms in Albania dates back to the 12th century, during the reign of the Byzantine Empire. The Byzantine Empire used a system of heraldry known as "ambiguitatem," which involved the use of simple symbols and emblems to identify military units and noble families.

### Regnum Albaniæ

In the 13th century, the Kingdom of Albania, also known as Regnum Albaniæ, was established by Charles of Anjou. The kingdom used a coat of arms featuring a double-headed eagle, which would later become a common symbol in Albanian heraldry.

### Feudal Lords

During the Middle Ages, Albania was divided into various feudal lordships, each with its own coat of arms. These coats of arms often featured symbols and emblems that reflected the lord's family history, territorial claims, and allegiances.

Albanian Nobility
-----------------

The Albanian nobility has a long and complex history, with various families rising to prominence over the centuries. The use of coats of arms among the Albanian nobility reflects this history, with many families adopting coats of arms that reflect their ancestry, territorial claims, and cultural influences.

### Austria-Hungary

During the 19th and early 20th centuries, Albania was part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. As a result, many Albanian noble families adopted coats of arms that reflected their connections to the empire.

### Italian States

Albania has a long history of cultural and economic ties to Italy, and many Albanian noble families have adopted coats of arms that reflect these connections.

#### La Serenìssima

The Venetian Republic, also known as La Serenìssima, had a significant influence on the use of coats of arms in Albania. Many Albanian noble families adopted coats of arms that featured symbols and emblems associated with the Venetian Republic.

#### Albania Vèneta

Albania Vèneta, also known as Venetian Albania, was a historical region that corresponded to the modern-day Albanian coast. The region was under Venetian control from the 14th to the 18th centuries, and many local noble families adopted coats of arms that reflected their connections to the Venetian Republic.

#### Dalmatia

Dalmatia, a historical region that corresponds to the modern-day Croatian coast, was also under Venetian control during the Middle Ages. Many Albanian noble families had connections to Dalmatia, and their coats of arms often reflected these ties.

#### Istria

Istria, a peninsula in modern-day Croatia, was also under Venetian control during the Middle Ages. Many Albanian noble families had connections to Istria, and their coats of arms often reflected these ties.

### Dicio Pontificia

The Papal States, also known as Dicio Pontificia, had a significant influence on the use of coats of arms in Albania. Many Albanian noble families adopted coats of arms that featured symbols and emblems associated with the Papal States.

### Genoa, Neapolis, Sicilia...

Other Italian states, such as Genoa, Naples, and Sicily, also had an influence on the use of coats of arms in Albania. Many Albanian noble families adopted coats of arms that reflected their connections to these states.

Moldavia & Romania
-----------------

Albania has a long history of cultural and economic ties to Moldavia and Romania. Many Albanian noble families adopted coats of arms that reflected these connections.

Greece
------

Albania has a long history of cultural and economic ties to Greece. Many Albanian noble families adopted coats of arms that reflected these connections.

Ottoman Empire
-------------

Albania was part of the Ottoman Empire from the 14th to the 20th centuries. As a result, many Albanian noble families adopted coats of arms that reflected their connections to the empire.

### Grand Viziers

The Grand Viziers of the Ottoman Empire often used coats of arms that reflected their family history and territorial claims. Many Albanian noble families adopted similar coats of arms, reflecting their connections to the empire.

Egypt
-----

Albania has a long history of cultural and economic ties to Egypt. Many Albanian noble families adopted coats of arms that reflected these connections.

Modern Period
-------------

In the modern period, the use of coats of arms in Albania has continued to evolve. Many families have adopted new coats of arms that reflect their modern identities and connections.

Ecclesiastical Coats of Arms
-------------------------

The use of coats of arms in the Albanian Orthodox Church and the Catholic Church in Albania reflects the country's complex history and cultural influences.

### Coats of Arms

Many Albanian Orthodox and Catholic churches use coats of arms that reflect their connections to the broader Christian tradition.

### Seals

The use of seals in the Albanian Orthodox and Catholic churches reflects the country's rich tradition of ecclesiastical heraldry.

In Society
------------

The use of coats of arms in Albanian society reflects the country's complex history and cultural influences. Many families and institutions continue to use coats of arms as a way of identifying themselves and their connections to the broader world.

article:
Ole Miss riot of 1962

The Ole Miss riot of 1962 was a violent confrontation between federal authorities and students from the University of Mississippi (also known as Ole Miss) on September 30, 1962. The riot was sparked by the attempted enrollment of James Meredith, an African American student, at the previously all-white institution. The event marked a significant milestone in the American Civil Rights Movement and highlighted the deep-seated racial tensions in the United States during the 1960s.

# Leadup

## Meredith's attempts to enroll

In January 1961, James Meredith, a 28-year-old African American veteran, applied to the University of Mississippi, citing his right to attend the institution under the 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution. Meredith's application was initially rejected, but he persisted, filing a lawsuit against the university in May 1961. The case eventually made its way to the U.S. Supreme Court, which ruled in Meredith's favor on September 10, 1962.

## Kennedy dialogue and escalating tensions

In the months leading up to Meredith's enrollment, tensions in Mississippi escalated. Governor Ross Barnett, a staunch segregationist, vowed to block Meredith's admission, while President John F. Kennedy attempted to reason with Barnett through a series of phone calls. Kennedy urged Barnett to respect the law and allow Meredith to enroll, but Barnett refused, citing concerns about public safety and the potential for violence.

As the standoff between Kennedy and Barnett continued, the situation on the Ole Miss campus grew increasingly volatile. Students and faculty members alike were divided on the issue of integration, with many expressing opposition to Meredith's enrollment. In the days leading up to September 30, the campus was filled with the sound of protesters chanting slogans and waving Confederate flags.

# Events

## Meredith arrives

On September 30, 1962, James Meredith arrived at the Ole Miss campus, accompanied by a small group of federal marshals. The group was met by a crowd of angry students, who had gathered to protest Meredith's enrollment. As the marshals attempted to escort Meredith to the university's administration building, the crowd surged forward, blocking their path.

## Violence on campus

The situation quickly spiraled out of control as protesters began throwing rocks and bottles at the federal marshals. The marshals responded by firing tear gas into the crowd, but the protesters continued to advance. Meredith was eventually forced to take cover in a nearby dormitory, where he was protected by a group of federal agents.

As the violence escalated, the Ole Miss campus descended into chaos. Buildings were set on fire, and cars were overturned. The sounds of gunfire and breaking glass filled the air, and the smell of tear gas hung heavy over the campus.

## Military response

As the situation on campus continued to deteriorate, President Kennedy deployed a group of U.S. Army troops to Oxford, Mississippi. The troops, who arrived on the evening of September 30, were tasked with restoring order and ensuring Meredith's safety.

The military response was swift and decisive. The troops moved quickly to disperse the crowd, using bayonets and tear gas to restore order. The violence eventually subsided, and Meredith was escorted safely to his dormitory.

## Aftermath

The Ole Miss riot of 1962 left two people dead and over 300 injured. The event marked a turning point in the American Civil Rights Movement, highlighting the need for federal intervention to protect the rights of African Americans.

In the aftermath of the riot, James Meredith continued to face harassment and intimidation from his fellow students. Despite these challenges, Meredith persevered, earning a degree in political science from Ole Miss in 1963.

# Legacy

The Ole Miss riot of 1962 had a profound impact on American society, highlighting the deep-seated racial tensions that existed in the United States during the 1960s. The event marked a significant milestone in the American Civil Rights Movement, demonstrating the need for federal intervention to protect the rights of African Americans.

Today, the University of Mississippi is a thriving institution, with a diverse student body and a strong commitment to social justice. James Meredith, who went on to earn a law degree from Columbia University, continues to be an important figure in American civil rights history.

# Notes and references

## Notes

This article is based on historical records and accounts of the Ole Miss riot of 1962.

War Crimes in the Russian Invasion of Ukraine

The Russian invasion of Ukraine, which began in February 2022, has been marked by numerous allegations of war crimes committed by Russian forces. These allegations include the use of prohibited weapons, abduction and deportation of civilians, attacks on civilian targets, and mistreatment of prisoners of war. The international community has widely condemned these actions, and numerous investigations are underway to document and prosecute those responsible.

#Prohibited Weapons

Russian forces have been accused of using prohibited weapons, including cluster munitions and phosphorus bombs, in civilian areas. The use of such weapons is banned under international humanitarian law, as they cause indiscriminate harm to civilians and can have long-lasting effects on the environment. The Ukrainian government has reported numerous instances of cluster munition use, including in the cities of Kyiv and Kharkiv.

article:
Speak Now (Taylor's Version)
==========================

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) is the re-recorded version of Taylor Swift's 2010 album Speak Now. The album marks Swift's decision to re-record her older albums following the highly publicized dispute over the ownership of her master recordings. Speak Now (Taylor's Version) features re-recorded versions of the original tracks, as well as six additional "From the Vault" tracks, which were written and recorded during the original album's creation but did not make the final cut.

Background
----------

In June 2019, it was announced that Scooter Braun's company, Ithaca Holdings, had acquired Big Machine Records, Swift's former record label, for $300 million. As a result, Braun's company acquired the rights to Swift's master recordings from her 2006 debut album to 2017's reputation. Swift publicly expressed her disapproval of the deal, stating that she had not been given the opportunity to purchase her master recordings herself and that Braun's ownership of her music was a "worst-case scenario" for her.

In August 2020, Swift announced that she would be re-recording her older albums in an effort to regain control over her master recordings. Speak Now (Taylor's Version) is the second re-recorded album Swift has released, following Fearless (Taylor's Version), which was released in April 2021.

Music and lyrics
----------------

### Composition

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) features re-recorded versions of the original album's 14 tracks, as well as six additional "From the Vault" tracks. The album's production is notable for its use of a more stripped-back, acoustic sound, with Swift's vocals and guitar work taking center stage. The album's sound is often described as country-pop, with influences from folk, rock, and pop music.

The album's lyrics are characterized by their introspective and personal nature, with Swift addressing themes of love, heartbreak, and self-discovery. Many of the album's tracks are based on Swift's own experiences and relationships, with some songs featuring direct references to her personal life.

### "From the Vault" tracks

The six "From the Vault" tracks featured on Speak Now (Taylor's Version) were written and recorded during the original album's creation but did not make the final cut. These tracks offer a glimpse into Swift's creative process and provide insight into the album's original vision. The "From the Vault" tracks feature a similar sound and style to the original album, with Swift's vocals and guitar work taking center stage.

--------

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) was released on July 7, 2023, through Republic Records. The album was announced in May 2023, with Swift releasing a series of teasers and promotional materials in the lead-up to the album's release. The album was made available on various streaming platforms, including Spotify, Apple Music, and Amazon Music.

Critical reception
-----------------

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) received widespread critical acclaim upon its release, with many reviewers praising Swift's vocals, songwriting, and production. The album's re-recorded tracks were praised for their updated sound and style, while the "From the Vault" tracks were praised for their insight into Swift's creative process.

Commercial performance
--------------------

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart, with first-week sales of over 200,000 copies. The album also reached number one on the UK Albums Chart, the Australian Albums Chart, and the Canadian Albums Chart.

Recognition

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) has been recognized for its contributions to music, with the album receiving several awards and nominations. The album was nominated for Album of the Year at the 2024 Grammy Awards.

article:
Kokshetau is a city located in the north of Kazakhstan, serving as the administrative center of Akmola Region. The city has a rich history dating back to the 19th century and has played a significant role in the country's development. Today, Kokshetau is a thriving urban center with a diverse economy, cultural attractions, and a strong sense of community.

# Names and etymology

The city's name has undergone several changes throughout its history. The original name, "Kokchetav," was derived from the Kazakh words "kok" meaning "blue" and "chetav" meaning "hills." The name referred to the city's location in the Blue Hills region.

## Chronology of name changes

* 1824: Founded as Kokchetav
* 1868: Renamed Kokchetavsk
* 1939: Renamed Kokchetav
* 1993: Renamed Kokshetau

# Physical geography and geology

Kokshetau is situated in the north of Kazakhstan, approximately 300 kilometers northwest of the capital city Astana. The city is located in the Kokchetav Depression, surrounded by the Blue Hills to the north and east, and the Kazakh Upland to the south and west.

## Location

Kokshetau is situated at an altitude of 234 meters above sea level, with a total area of 400 square kilometers. The city is bordered by the following districts: Arshaly, Astrakhan, and Sandyktau.

## Time

Kokshetau is located in the Eastern European Time Zone (UTC+6).

## Climate

Kokshetau has a continental climate, characterized by cold winters and warm summers. The average temperature in January, the coldest month, is -15°C, while the average temperature in July, the warmest month, is 20°C. The city experiences moderate precipitation, with an average annual rainfall of 350 millimeters.

# Legal status and administrative-territorial division

Kokshetau is a city of regional significance, serving as the administrative center of Akmola Region. The city is divided into several administrative districts and microdistricts.

## Administrative districts and microdistricts

* Almaty District
* Auezov District
* Zheltoksan District
* Kokchetav District
* Microdistricts: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9

## Districts

* Akmola Region is divided into 17 districts, with Kokshetau serving as the regional center.

# Authorities, local government and politics

Kokshetau is governed by the city's authorities, as well as regional authorities.

## Kokshetau authorities

* City Akim (Mayor): appointed by the President of Kazakhstan
* City Maslikhat: a representative body composed of 30 deputies elected by the city's residents

## Regional authorities

* Regional Akim: appointed by the President of Kazakhstan
* Regional Maslikhat: a representative body composed of 30 deputies elected by the region's residents

### List of akims (mayors) of Kokshetau (1992–present)

### Politics

Kokshetau has a stable political environment, with the ruling Nur Otan party holding a majority of seats in the city and regional maslikhats. Opposition parties are also represented, with the most prominent being the Democratic Party of Kazakhstan.

# History

Kokshetau has a rich history dating back to the 19th century.

## Early history

The area around Kokshetau was first inhabited by nomadic tribes, with archaeological findings dating back to the Bronze Age. In the 19th century, the region became a major center for trade and commerce, with the establishment of the Kokchetav Fair.

## Foundation of Kokshetau (1824–1917)

The city was founded in 1824 as a fortification to protect the region from invading tribes. The city quickly grew, with the establishment of a mosque, a school, and several shops. In 1868, the city was renamed Kokchetavsk and became a major center for the region's agricultural production.

## Soviet era (1918–1991)

Following the Russian Revolution, Kokshetau became a major center for the region's industrialization, with the establishment of several factories and plants. The city also became a major cultural center, with the establishment of a theater, a museum, and a library.

## Fall of the Soviet Union and modern history (1991–present)

article:
2022–23 Australian region cyclone season

The 2022–23 Australian region cyclone season was a period of tropical cyclone formation that occurred in the southern hemisphere during the 2022–23 tropical cyclone year. The season officially began on 1 November 2022 and ended on 30 April 2023. During this time, a total of 12 tropical cyclones formed in the Australian region, with 6 of them reaching severe tropical cyclone strength.

# Season forecasts

Before the start of the season, several meteorological agencies issued forecasts for the number of tropical cyclones that would form in the Australian region. The Australian Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) predicted a near-average season, with 9-12 tropical cyclones expected to form. The BOM also noted that the chances of a La Niña event, which tends to enhance tropical cyclone activity in the region, were high.

# Season summary

The 2022–23 Australian region cyclone season was marked by a relatively slow start, with only two tropical cyclones forming in the first two months of the season. However, activity picked up in January, with four tropical cyclones forming in the month. The season saw a total of 12 tropical cyclones form, with 6 of them reaching severe tropical cyclone strength. One of the most notable systems of the season was Severe Tropical Cyclone Freddy, which brought significant damage and flooding to Western Australia.

# Systems

## Tropical Cyclone 01U

The first tropical cyclone of the season formed on 10 November 2022 in the Arafura Sea. The system moved slowly southwards and made landfall in the Northern Territory on 12 November. The cyclone brought moderate rainfall to the region, but caused no significant damage.

## Tropical Low 02U

Tropical Low 02U formed on 15 November 2022 in the Gulf of Carpentaria. The system moved slowly eastwards and entered the Coral Sea, where it dissipated on 19 November.

## Severe Tropical Cyclone Darian

Severe Tropical Cyclone Darian formed on 12 January 2023 in the Indian Ocean. The system moved slowly southwestwards and reached severe tropical cyclone strength on 15 January. Darian passed close to the Cocos Islands, bringing strong winds and heavy rainfall.

## Tropical Cyclone Ellie

Tropical Cyclone Ellie formed on 20 January 2023 in the Coral Sea. The system moved slowly southwards and made landfall in Queensland on 23 January. Ellie brought moderate rainfall to the region, but caused no significant damage.

## Tropical Low 07U (Hale)

Tropical Low 07U formed on 30 January 2023 in the Gulf of Carpentaria. The system moved slowly eastwards and entered the Coral Sea, where it dissipated on 3 February.

## Tropical Low 10U

Tropical Low 10U formed on 10 February 2023 in the Arafura Sea. The system moved slowly southwards and made landfall in the Northern Territory on 12 February.

## Tropical Low 11U (Dingani)

Tropical Low 11U formed on 15 February 2023 in the Indian Ocean. The system moved slowly southwestwards and dissipated on 19 February.

## Tropical Low 12U

Tropical Low 12U formed on 20 February 2023 in the Coral Sea. The system moved slowly southwards and dissipated on 23 February.

## Severe Tropical Cyclone Freddy

Severe Tropical Cyclone Freddy formed on 4 March 2023 in the Indian Ocean. The system moved slowly southwestwards and reached severe tropical cyclone strength on 6 March. Freddy passed close to Western Australia, bringing strong winds and heavy rainfall.

## Severe Tropical Cyclone Gabrielle

Severe Tropical Cyclone Gabrielle formed on 10 March 2023 in the Coral Sea. The system moved slowly southwards and reached severe tropical cyclone strength on 12 March. Gabrielle passed close to New Caledonia, bringing strong winds and heavy rainfall.

## Tropical Low 15U

Tropical Low 15U formed on 20 March 2023 in the Arafura Sea. The system moved slowly southwards and dissipated on 22 March.

## Tropical Low 16U

Tropical Low 16U formed on 25 March 2023 in the Gulf of Carpentaria. The system moved slowly eastwards and dissipated on 28 March.

## Tropical Low 17U

Tropical Low 17U formed on 30 March 2023 in the Coral Sea. The system moved slowly southwards and dissipated on 2 April.

## Tropical Low 18U (Kevin)

Tropical Low 18U formed on 5 April 2023 in the Indian Ocean. The system moved slowly southwestwards and dissipated on 9 April.

## Tropical Low 20U

Tropical Low 20U formed on 15 April 2023 in the Arafura Sea. The system moved slowly southwards and dissipated on 17 April.

## Severe Tropical Cyclone Herman

Severe Tropical Cyclone Herman formed on 20 April 2023 in the Coral Sea. The system moved slowly southwards and reached severe tropical cyclone strength on 22 April.

## Tropical Low 22U

Tropical Low 22U formed on 25 April 2023 in the Gulf of Carpentaria. The system moved slowly eastwards and dissipated on 28 April.

## Severe Tropical Cyclone Ilsa

Severe Tropical Cyclone Ilsa formed on 28 April 2023 in the Indian Ocean. The system moved slowly southwestwards and reached severe tropical cyclone strength on 30 April.

## Other systems

In addition to the systems listed above, several other tropical lows and cyclones formed in the Australian region during the 2022-23 season. These systems did not reach tropical cyclone strength, but still brought significant rainfall and wind to the region.

# Storm names

## Bureau of Meteorology

The Australian Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) is responsible for naming tropical cyclones in the Australian region. The BOM uses a list of names that are assigned to systems in alphabetical order. The names are chosen from a list of submissions from the public and are intended to be easy to pronounce and remember.

## TCWC Jakarta

The Tropical Cyclone Warning Centre (TCWC) in Jakarta, Indonesia is responsible for naming tropical cyclones in the eastern Indian Ocean. The TCWC uses a list of names that are assigned to systems in alphabetical order.

## TCWC Port Moresby

The Tropical Cyclone Warning Centre (TCWC) in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea is responsible for naming tropical cyclones in the southern Pacific Ocean. The TCWC uses a list of names that are assigned to systems in alphabetical order.

## Retirement

The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) is responsible for retiring the names of tropical cyclones that have caused significant damage or loss of life. The WMO retires the names of systems that have reached tropical cyclone strength and have caused significant damage or loss of life.

# Season effects

The 2022-23 Australian region cyclone season had a significant impact on the region, with several systems bringing strong winds and heavy rainfall. The season saw a total of 12 tropical cyclones form, with 6 of them reaching severe tropical cyclone strength. One of the most notable systems of the season was Severe Tropical Cyclone Freddy, which brought significant damage and flooding to Western Australia.
